target:
||| Mohammed Abdul Karim (1863 — 20 April 1909), also called "the Munshi", was an Indian who worked for Queen Victoria.  ||| He served her for the last 14 years of her rule, and she grew very fond of him like a mother.
==============
 ||| Karim was born to a hospital worker in Lalitpur, near Jhansi in British India.  ||| In 1887, when Victoria celebrated 50 years as queen, Karim was one of two Indians chosen to work for her.  ||| Victoria liked him a lot and gave him the title "Munshi" meaning "clerk" or "teacher".  ||| She made him her Indian Secretary, gave him many honors, and got him land in India.
==============
 ||| The close friendship between Karim and the Queen caused problems in the Royal Household because the other members thought they were better than him.  ||| The Queen wanted Karim to travel with her, which led to arguments with her other staff.  ||| After Victoria died in 1901, the new king, Edward VII, sent Karim back to India and ordered that his letters with Victoria be taken and destroyed.  ||| Karim then lived quietly near Agra on the land Victoria had given him, until he died at the age of 46.

source: ||| Mohammed Abdul Karim (1863 — 20 April 1909), also known as "the Munshi", was an Indian attendant of Queen Victoria.  ||| He served her during the final fourteen years of her reign, gaining her maternal affection over that time.  ||| Karim was born the son of a hospital assistant at Lalitpur, near Jhansi in British India.  ||| In 1887, the year of Victoria's Golden Jubilee, Karim was one of two Indians selected to become servants to the Queen.  ||| Victoria came to like him a great deal and gave him the title of "Munshi" ("clerk" or "teacher").  ||| Victoria appointed him to be her Indian Secretary, showered him with honours, and obtained a land grant for him in India.  ||| The close platonic relationship between Karim and the Queen led to friction within the Royal Household, the other members of which felt themselves to be superior to him.  ||| The Queen insisted on taking Karim with her on her travels, which caused arguments between her and her other attendants.  ||| Following Victoria's death in 1901, her successor, Edward VII, returned Karim to India and ordered the confiscation and destruction of the Munshi's correspondence with Victoria.  ||| Karim subsequently lived quietly near Agra, on the estate that Victoria had arranged for him, until his death at the age of 46.

||| Mohammed Abdul Karim (1863 — 20 April 1909), also called "the Munshi", was an Indian who worked for Queen Victoria.  ||| He served her for the last 14 years of her rule, and she grew very fond of him like a mother.
==============
 ||| Karim was born to a hospital worker in Lalitpur, near Jhansi in British India.  ||| In 1887, when Victoria celebrated 50 years as queen, Karim was one of two Indians chosen to work for her.  ||| Victoria liked him a lot and gave him the title "Munshi" meaning "clerk" or "teacher".  ||| She made him her Indian Secretary, gave him many honors, and got him land in India.
==============
 ||| The close friendship between Karim and the Queen caused problems in the Royal Household because the other members thought they were better than him.  ||| The Queen wanted Karim to travel with her, which led to arguments with her other staff.  ||| After Victoria died in 1901, the new king, Edward VII, sent Karim back to India and ordered that his letters with Victoria be taken and destroyed.  ||| Karim then lived quietly near Agra on the land Victoria had given him, until he died at the age of 46.

||| Mohammed Abdul Karim was an Indian man who worked for Queen Victoria of England.  ||| He served her for the last 14 years of her life, from 1887 to 1901.  ||| The Queen grew very fond of him during this time.
==============
 ||| Karim was born in India in 1863.  ||| His father worked in a hospital.  ||| In 1887, when Queen Victoria was celebrating 50 years as queen, Karim was chosen to be one of her servants.
==============
 ||| Queen Victoria liked Karim very much.  ||| She gave him the title "Munshi," which means teacher or clerk.  ||| She made him her Indian Secretary and gave him many honors.  ||| She also helped him get some land in India.
==============
 ||| The Queen and Karim had a close friendship, but this caused problems with other people who worked for the Queen.  ||| They thought they were better than Karim and didn't like how close he was to the Queen.  ||| There were often arguments when the Queen wanted to take Karim with her on trips.
==============
 ||| When Queen Victoria died in 1901, her son became King Edward VII.  ||| He sent Karim back to India and ordered that all of Karim's letters from the Queen be destroyed.  ||| Karim then lived quietly on the land the Queen had given him near Agra, India.  ||| He died in 1909 when he was 46 years old.

source: ||| Mohammed Abdul Karim (1863 — 20 April 1909), also known as "the Munshi", was an Indian attendant of Queen Victoria.  ||| He served her during the final fourteen years of her reign, gaining her maternal affection over that time.  ||| Karim was born the son of a hospital assistant at Lalitpur, near Jhansi in British India.  ||| In 1887, the year of Victoria's Golden Jubilee, Karim was one of two Indians selected to become servants to the Queen.  ||| Victoria came to like him a great deal and gave him the title of "Munshi" ("clerk" or "teacher").  ||| Victoria appointed him to be her Indian Secretary, showered him with honours, and obtained a land grant for him in India.  ||| The close platonic relationship between Karim and the Queen led to friction within the Royal Household, the other members of which felt themselves to be superior to him.  ||| The Queen insisted on taking Karim with her on her travels, which caused arguments between her and her other attendants.  ||| Following Victoria's death in 1901, her successor, Edward VII, returned Karim to India and ordered the confiscation and destruction of the Munshi's correspondence with Victoria.  ||| Karim subsequently lived quietly near Agra, on the estate that Victoria had arranged for him, until his death at the age of 46.

||| Mohammed Abdul Karim, who was called “the Munshi,” was an Indian helper who worked for Queen Victoria.  ||| He worked for her during the last fourteen years of her life and she grew to care for him a lot.
==============
 ||| Karim was born in India near Jhansi to a man who worked in a hospital.  ||| In 1887, when Queen Victoria celebrated her Golden Jubilee, he was one of two Indians chosen to be servants to the Queen.  ||| Queen Victoria really liked him and gave him the title “Munshi,” which means “clerk” or “teacher.” She then made him her Indian Secretary, gave him special honors, and even helped him get land in India.
==============
 ||| Because of the close friendship between Karim and the Queen, some people in the royal household felt he wasn’t good enough for them.  ||| The Queen insisted on taking Karim with her on her trips, which caused disagreements with her other helpers.  ||| After Queen Victoria died in 1901, her son, King Edward VII, sent Karim back to India and had all of his letters to the Queen destroyed.  ||| Karim then lived peacefully near Agra, on the land the Queen had provided for him, until he died at age 46.

source: ||| Mohammed Abdul Karim (1863 — 20 April 1909), also known as "the Munshi", was an Indian attendant of Queen Victoria.  ||| He served her during the final fourteen years of her reign, gaining her maternal affection over that time.  ||| Karim was born the son of a hospital assistant at Lalitpur, near Jhansi in British India.  ||| In 1887, the year of Victoria's Golden Jubilee, Karim was one of two Indians selected to become servants to the Queen.  ||| Victoria came to like him a great deal and gave him the title of "Munshi" ("clerk" or "teacher").  ||| Victoria appointed him to be her Indian Secretary, showered him with honours, and obtained a land grant for him in India.  ||| The close platonic relationship between Karim and the Queen led to friction within the Royal Household, the other members of which felt themselves to be superior to him.  ||| The Queen insisted on taking Karim with her on her travels, which caused arguments between her and her other attendants.  ||| Following Victoria's death in 1901, her successor, Edward VII, returned Karim to India and ordered the confiscation and destruction of the Munshi's correspondence with Victoria.  ||| Karim subsequently lived quietly near Agra, on the estate that Victoria had arranged for him, until his death at the age of 46.
